konaneCommon
Class Player

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--konaneCommon.Player
public abstract class Player
extends java.lang.Object

The player who makes moves for the team.

The Player class represents the individual player who competes for a team in the tournament by computing and returning moves to the game engine.

Team submissions should extend this abstract class and override the makeMove(konaneCommon.BoardGrid, long) method, which is the entry point into team-written code. If a Player needs to run initialization code, the constructor should be overridden but should take no parameters. You should not call the setSide(byte) method for any reason.

More details on writing your solution can be found in the readme.txt file.

Version:
1.9, 17 January 2001
Author:
Paul Pham

Field Detail

side

protected byte side
Byte representing the side of this Player in the current game. Sides are represented by byte constants defined in Konane. You can refer to this variable in your subclass if your algorithm depends on the Player's side.
See Also:
Konane.WHITE, Konane.BLACK
Constructor Detail

Player

public Player()
Empty constructor. This constructor, which takes no parameters, is necessary for loading and instantiating this class programmatically. If you need to perform initialization for your Playersubclass, override this constructor but do not take any parameters.
Method Detail

makeMove

public abstract Move makeMove(BoardGrid oldBoard,
                              long allowedTime)
The entry point into player execution.

Override this method to implement your gameplaying algorithm. Note that allowedTime is initialized at the beginning of each game to the total time allocated to each player for making all of their moves; as in timed chess matches, it is up to the player how to distribute their time among moves. makeMove is called with successively smaller values of allowedTime as the player's time limit is decremented by the time elapsed during its last move. Player who let their allowedTime drop below 0 will be disqualified. Consult the readme.txt file for more details about writing your solution.

Parameters:
oldBoard - the Konane gameboard before you make a move. You do not need to keep track of this board, since an up-to-date board will passed to this method each time you are required to make a move.
allowedTime - the total number of milliseconds you have left in this game to make moves. You do not need to keep track of this time, since it will be passed to this method each time you are required to make a move.
Returns:
a valid Move or a voluntary forfeit. A null move will count as an error and an involuntary forfeit.

setSide

public final void setSide(byte side)
Sets the Player's side. Sides are represented by byte constants defined in Konane. You will never need to call this method.
Parameters:
side - a byte constant representing the side of the player.
See Also:
Konane.WHITE, Konane.BLACK
